Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Deep beneath the geysers and hot springs 
of Yellowstone Caldera lies a magma chamber produced by a 
hot spot in the earth’s mantle. As the magma moves towards 
the Earth’s surface, it crystallizes to form young, 
hot igneous rocks. The heat from these rocks drives 
groundwater towards the surface. As the water cools, ions precipitate out 
as mineral crystals, including quartz crystals from silicon 
and oxygen, feldspar from potassium, aluminum, 
silicon, and oxygen, galena from lead and sulfur. Many of these crystals have signature 
shapes— take this cascade of pointed quartz, 
or this pile of galena cubes. But what causes them to grow into these
shapes again and again? Part of the answer lies in their atoms. Every crystal’s atoms are arranged 
in a highly organized, repeating pattern. This pattern is the defining 
feature of a crystal, and isn’t restricted to minerals— sand, ice, sugar, chocolate, ceramics, 
metals, DNA, and even some liquids have 
crystalline structures. Each crystalline material’s atomic 
arrangement falls into one of six different families: cubic, tetragonal, orthorhombic, 
monoclinic, triclinic, and hexagonal. Given the appropriate conditions, crystals will grow into geometric shapes that reflect the arrangement 
of their atoms. Take galena, which has a cubic structure 
composed of lead and sulfur atoms. The relatively large lead atoms are arranged in a three-dimensional 
grid 90 degrees from one another, while the relatively small sulfur atoms 
fit neatly between them. As the crystal grows, locations like these
attract sulfur atoms, while lead will tend to 
bond to these places. Eventually, they will complete the grid 
of bonded atoms. This means the 90 degree grid pattern 
of galena’s crystalline structure is reflected in the visible 
shape of the crystal. Quartz, meanwhile, has a hexagonal 
crystalline structure. This means that on one plane its atoms 
are arranged in hexagons. In three dimensions, these hexagons are 
composed of many interlocking pyramids made up of one silicon atom 
and four oxygen atoms. So the signature shape of a quartz 
crystal is a six-sided column with pointed tips. Depending on environmental conditions, most crystals have the potential to form
multiple geometric shapes. For example, diamonds, which form deep
in the Earth’s mantle, have a cubic crystalline structure and can
grow into either cubes or octahedrons. Which shape a particular 
diamond grows into depends on the conditions where it grows, including pressure, temperature, 
and chemical environment. While we can’t directly observe growth 
conditions in the mantle, laboratory experiments have shown some
evidence that diamonds tend to grow into cubes at 
lower temperatures and octahedrons at higher temperatures. Trace amounts of water, silicon, 
germanium, or magnesium might also influence a diamond’s shape. And diamonds never naturally grow into the
shapes found in jewelry— those diamonds have been cut to 
showcase sparkle and clarity. Environmental conditions can also 
influence whether crystals form at all. Glass is made of melted quartz sand, but it isn’t crystalline. That’s because glass cools 
relatively quickly, and the atoms do not have time to arrange
themselves into the ordered structure 
of a quartz crystal. Instead, the random arrangement 
of the atoms in the melted glass is locked in upon cooling. Many crystals don’t form geometric shapes because they grow in extremely close 
quarters with other crystals. Rocks like granite are full of crystals, but none have recognizable shapes. As magma cools and solidifies, many minerals within it crystallize at the
same time and quickly run out of space. And certain crystals, like turquoise, don’t grow into any discernible geometric
shape in most environmental conditions, even given adequate space. Every crystal’s atomic structure has 
unique properties, and while these properties may not have
any bearing on human emotional needs, they do have powerful applications 
in materials science and medicine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What elements make up the mineral galena?
Options: A. Silicon and oxygen, B. Potassium, aluminum, silicon, and oxygen, C. Sodium and chlorine, D. Lead and sulfur
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason for the formation of crystals in the Earth's crust? Options: A. The cooling of magma, B. The movement of tectonic plates, C. The presence of groundwater, D. The interaction of Earth's magnetic field Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a crystal? Options: A. Highly organized atomic arrangement, B. Highly disorganized atomic arrangement, C. Repeating pattern of atoms, D. Geometric shape Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the family of crystalline structures that includes quartz? Options: A. Cubic, B. Tetragonal, C. Hexagonal, D. Triclinic Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following crystals has a cubic crystalline structure? Options: A. Galena, B. Quartz, C. Diamond, D. Turquoise Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary factor that determines the shape of a diamond crystal? Options: A. Temperature, B. Pressure, C. Chemical environment, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the process by which glass is made? Options: A. Crystallization, B. Melting, C. Cooling, D. Quenching Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why do crystals in rocks like granite not have recognizable shapes? Options: A. Because they grow in extremely close quarters with other crystals, B. Because they are made of a different type of mineral, C. Because they are formed at high temperatures, D. Because they are formed at low pressures Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the family of crystalline structures that includes feldspar? Options: A. Cubic, B. Tetragonal, C. Orthorhombic, D. Monoclinic Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the primary application of crystals in materials science? Options: A. Their ability to conduct electricity, B. Their ability to conduct heat, C. Their unique properties, D. Their geometric shapes Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why do crystals like quartz not form geometric shapes in most environmental conditions? Options: A. Because they grow too quickly, B. Because they grow too slowly, C. Because they grow in extremely close quarters with other crystals, D. Because they are made of a different type of mineral Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: Which of the following crystals has a cubic crystalline structure? Options: A. Galena, B. Quartz, C. Diamond, D. Turquoise.

Although the question is not an exact match, the options provided include galena, which is the mineral mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Deep beneath the geysers and hot springs 
of Yellowstone Caldera lies a magma chamber produced by a 
hot spot in the earth’s mantle. As the magma moves towards 
the Earth’s surface, it crystallizes to form young, 
hot igneous rocks. The heat from these rocks drives 
groundwater towards the surface. As the water cools, ions precipitate out 
as mineral crystals, including quartz crystals from silicon 
and oxygen, feldspar from potassium, aluminum, 
silicon, and oxygen, galena from lead and sulfur. Many of these crystals have signature 
shapes— take this cascade of pointed quartz, 
or this pile of galena cubes. But what causes them to grow into these
shapes again and again? Part of the answer lies in their atoms. Every crystal’s atoms are arranged 
in a highly organized, repeating pattern. This pattern is the defining 
feature of a crystal, and isn’t restricted to minerals— sand, ice, sugar, chocolate, ceramics, 
metals, DNA, and even some liquids have 
crystalline structures. Each crystalline material’s atomic 
arrangement falls into one of six different families: cubic, tetragonal, orthorhombic, 
monoclinic, triclinic, and hexagonal. Given the appropriate conditions, crystals will grow into geometric shapes that reflect the arrangement 
of their atoms. Take galena, which has a cubic structure 
composed of lead and sulfur atoms. The relatively large lead atoms are arranged in a three-dimensional 
grid 90 degrees from one another, while the relatively small sulfur atoms 
fit neatly between them. As the crystal grows, locations like these
attract sulfur atoms, while lead will tend to 
bond to these places. Eventually, they will complete the grid 
of bonded atoms. This means the 90 degree grid pattern 
of galena’s crystalline structure is reflected in the visible 
shape of the crystal. Quartz, meanwhile, has a hexagonal 
crystalline structure. This means that on one plane its atoms 
are arranged in hexagons. In three dimensions, these hexagons are 
composed of many interlocking pyramids made up of one silicon atom 
and four oxygen atoms. So the signature shape of a quartz 
crystal is a six-sided column with pointed tips. Depending on environmental conditions, most crystals have the potential to form
multiple geometric shapes. For example, diamonds, which form deep
in the Earth’s mantle, have a cubic crystalline structure and can
grow into either cubes or octahedrons. Which shape a particular 
diamond grows into depends on the conditions where it grows, including pressure, temperature, 
and chemical environment. While we can’t directly observe growth 
conditions in the mantle, laboratory experiments have shown some
evidence that diamonds tend to grow into cubes at 
lower temperatures and octahedrons at higher temperatures. Trace amounts of water, silicon, 
germanium, or magnesium might also influence a diamond’s shape. And diamonds never naturally grow into the
shapes found in jewelry— those diamonds have been cut to 
showcase sparkle and clarity. Environmental conditions can also 
influence whether crystals form at all. Glass is made of melted quartz sand, but it isn’t crystalline. That’s because glass cools 
relatively quickly, and the atoms do not have time to arrange
themselves into the ordered structure 
of a quartz crystal. Instead, the random arrangement 
of the atoms in the melted glass is locked in upon cooling. Many crystals don’t form geometric shapes because they grow in extremely close 
quarters with other crystals. Rocks like granite are full of crystals, but none have recognizable shapes. As magma cools and solidifies, many minerals within it crystallize at the
same time and quickly run out of space. And certain crystals, like turquoise, don’t grow into any discernible geometric
shape in most environmental conditions, even given adequate space. Every crystal’s atomic structure has 
unique properties, and while these properties may not have
any bearing on human emotional needs, they do have powerful applications 
in materials science and medicine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How are the atoms generally arranged in crystals?
Options: A. Randomly, B. Always in a highly organized, repeating way, C. Always in a double helix, D. Scientists have not figured this out yet
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason for the formation of crystals in the Earth's crust? Options: A. The cooling of magma, B. The movement of tectonic plates, C. The presence of groundwater, D. The interaction of Earth's magnetic field Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a crystal? Options: A. Highly organized atomic arrangement, B. Highly disorganized atomic arrangement, C. Repeating pattern of atoms, D. Geometric shape Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the family of crystalline structures that includes quartz? Options: A. Cubic, B. Tetragonal, C. Hexagonal, D. Triclinic Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following crystals has a cubic crystalline structure? Options: A. Galena, B. Quartz, C. Diamond, D. Turquoise Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary factor that determines the shape of a diamond crystal? Options: A. Temperature, B. Pressure, C. Chemical environment, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the process by which glass is made? Options: A. Crystallization, B. Melting, C. Cooling, D. Quenching Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why do crystals in rocks like granite not have recognizable shapes? Options: A. Because they grow in extremely close quarters with other crystals, B. Because they are made of a different type of mineral, C. Because they are formed at high temperatures, D. Because they are formed at low pressures Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the family of crystalline structures that includes feldspar? Options: A. Cubic, B. Tetragonal, C. Orthorhombic, D. Monoclinic Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the primary application of crystals in materials science? Options: A. Their ability to conduct electricity, B. Their ability to conduct heat, C. Their unique properties, D. Their geometric shapes Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why do crystals like quartz not form geometric shapes in most environmental conditions? Options: A. Because they grow too quickly, B. Because they grow too slowly, C. Because they grow in extremely close quarters with other crystals, D. Because they are made of a different type of mineral Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest match in terms of question intent and content. Question 2 asks about the characteristics of a crystal, and one of the options (A) mentions a "highly organized atomic arrangement", which aligns with the correct option (B) in the ground truth MCQ. However, the question and options in Question 2 are not identical to the ground truth MCQ.

It's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, but Question 2 is the closest match.

in materials science and medicine.

Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
Deep beneath the geysers and hot springs 
of Yellowstone Caldera lies a magma chamber produced by a 
hot spot in the earth’s mantle. As the magma moves towards 
the Earth’s surface, it crystallizes to form young, 
hot igneous rocks. The heat from these rocks drives 
groundwater towards the surface. As the water cools, ions precipitate out 
as mineral crystals, including quartz crystals from silicon 
and oxygen, feldspar from potassium, aluminum, 
silicon, and oxygen, galena from lead and sulfur. Many of these crystals have signature 
shapes— take this cascade of pointed quartz, 
or this pile of galena cubes. But what causes them to grow into these
shapes again and again? Part of the answer lies in their atoms. Every crystal’s atoms are arranged 
in a highly organized, repeating pattern. This pattern is the defining 
feature of a crystal, and isn’t restricted to minerals— sand, ice, sugar, chocolate, ceramics, 
metals, DNA, and even some liquids have 
crystalline structures. Each crystalline material’s atomic 
arrangement falls into one of six different families: cubic, tetragonal, orthorhombic, 
monoclinic, triclinic, and hexagonal. Given the appropriate conditions, crystals will grow into geometric shapes that reflect the arrangement 
of their atoms. Take galena, which has a cubic structure 
composed of lead and sulfur atoms. The relatively large lead atoms are arranged in a three-dimensional 
grid 90 degrees from one another, while the relatively small sulfur atoms 
fit neatly between them. As the crystal grows, locations like these
attract sulfur atoms, while lead will tend to 
bond to these places. Eventually, they will complete the grid 
of bonded atoms. This means the 90 degree grid pattern 
of galena’s crystalline structure is reflected in the visible 
shape of the crystal. Quartz, meanwhile, has a hexagonal 
crystalline structure. This means that on one plane its atoms 
are arranged in hexagons. In three dimensions, these hexagons are 
composed of many interlocking pyramids made up of one silicon atom 
and four oxygen atoms. So the signature shape of a quartz 
crystal is a six-sided column with pointed tips. Depending on environmental conditions, most crystals have the potential to form
multiple geometric shapes. For example, diamonds, which form deep
in the Earth’s mantle, have a cubic crystalline structure and can
grow into either cubes or octahedrons. Which shape a particular 
diamond grows into depends on the conditions where it grows, including pressure, temperature, 
and chemical environment. While we can’t directly observe growth 
conditions in the mantle, laboratory experiments have shown some
evidence that diamonds tend to grow into cubes at 
lower temperatures and octahedrons at higher temperatures. Trace amounts of water, silicon, 
germanium, or magnesium might also influence a diamond’s shape. And diamonds never naturally grow into the
shapes found in jewelry— those diamonds have been cut to 
showcase sparkle and clarity. Environmental conditions can also 
influence whether crystals form at all. Glass is made of melted quartz sand, but it isn’t crystalline. That’s because glass cools 
relatively quickly, and the atoms do not have time to arrange
themselves into the ordered structure 
of a quartz crystal. Instead, the random arrangement 
of the atoms in the melted glass is locked in upon cooling. Many crystals don’t form geometric shapes because they grow in extremely close 
quarters with other crystals. Rocks like granite are full of crystals, but none have recognizable shapes. As magma cools and solidifies, many minerals within it crystallize at the
same time and quickly run out of space. And certain crystals, like turquoise, don’t grow into any discernible geometric
shape in most environmental conditions, even given adequate space. Every crystal’s atomic structure has 
unique properties, and while these properties may not have
any bearing on human emotional needs, they do have powerful applications 
in materials science and medicine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why does glass have a random arrangement of atoms?
Options: A. The elements that make up glass does not allow its atoms to be arranged in an highly organized, repeating way, B. The random atomic arrangement of the liquid glass is locked in with fast cooling, C. The random atomic arrangement of the liquid glass is locked in with quick cooling, D. Because it wasn’t made by a volcano
Correct Option: C

Correct Option: B

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

Although the question content is not identical, the intent of Question 7 is similar to the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the requirement for a growing crystal to form a geometric shape, and the correct option is "There must be open space for the crystal to grow into." Question 7 asks why crystals in rocks like granite do not have recognizable shapes, and the correct option would be "Because they grow in extremely close quarters with other crystals," which implies that open space is necessary for a crystal to form a geometric shape.

The other generated MCQs do not match the ground truth MCQ as closely in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Deep beneath the geysers and hot springs 
of Yellowstone Caldera lies a magma chamber produced by a 
hot spot in the earth’s mantle. As the magma moves towards 
the Earth’s surface, it crystallizes to form young, 
hot igneous rocks. The heat from these rocks drives 
groundwater towards the surface. As the water cools, ions precipitate out 
as mineral crystals, including quartz crystals from silicon 
and oxygen, feldspar from potassium, aluminum, 
silicon, and oxygen, galena from lead and sulfur. Many of these crystals have signature 
shapes— take this cascade of pointed quartz, 
or this pile of galena cubes. But what causes them to grow into these
shapes again and again? Part of the answer lies in their atoms. Every crystal’s atoms are arranged 
in a highly organized, repeating pattern. This pattern is the defining 
feature of a crystal, and isn’t restricted to minerals— sand, ice, sugar, chocolate, ceramics, 
metals, DNA, and even some liquids have 
crystalline structures. Each crystalline material’s atomic 
arrangement falls into one of six different families: cubic, tetragonal, orthorhombic, 
monoclinic, triclinic, and hexagonal. Given the appropriate conditions, crystals will grow into geometric shapes that reflect the arrangement 
of their atoms. Take galena, which has a cubic structure 
composed of lead and sulfur atoms. The relatively large lead atoms are arranged in a three-dimensional 
grid 90 degrees from one another, while the relatively small sulfur atoms 
fit neatly between them. As the crystal grows, locations like these
attract sulfur atoms, while lead will tend to 
bond to these places. Eventually, they will complete the grid 
of bonded atoms. This means the 90 degree grid pattern 
of galena’s crystalline structure is reflected in the visible 
shape of the crystal. Quartz, meanwhile, has a hexagonal 
crystalline structure. This means that on one plane its atoms 
are arranged in hexagons. In three dimensions, these hexagons are 
composed of many interlocking pyramids made up of one silicon atom 
and four oxygen atoms. So the signature shape of a quartz 
crystal is a six-sided column with pointed tips. Depending on environmental conditions, most crystals have the potential to form
multiple geometric shapes. For example, diamonds, which form deep
in the Earth’s mantle, have a cubic crystalline structure and can
grow into either cubes or octahedrons. Which shape a particular 
diamond grows into depends on the conditions where it grows, including pressure, temperature, 
and chemical environment. While we can’t directly observe growth 
conditions in the mantle, laboratory experiments have shown some
evidence that diamonds tend to grow into cubes at 
lower temperatures and octahedrons at higher temperatures. Trace amounts of water, silicon, 
germanium, or magnesium might also influence a diamond’s shape. And diamonds never naturally grow into the
shapes found in jewelry— those diamonds have been cut to 
showcase sparkle and clarity. Environmental conditions can also 
influence whether crystals form at all. Glass is made of melted quartz sand, but it isn’t crystalline. That’s because glass cools 
relatively quickly, and the atoms do not have time to arrange
themselves into the ordered structure 
of a quartz crystal. Instead, the random arrangement 
of the atoms in the melted glass is locked in upon cooling. Many crystals don’t form geometric shapes because they grow in extremely close 
quarters with other crystals. Rocks like granite are full of crystals, but none have recognizable shapes. As magma cools and solidifies, many minerals within it crystallize at the
same time and quickly run out of space. And certain crystals, like turquoise, don’t grow into any discernible geometric
shape in most environmental conditions, even given adequate space. Every crystal’s atomic structure has 
unique properties, and while these properties may not have
any bearing on human emotional needs, they do have powerful applications 
in materials science and medicine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is origin of the shapes of diamond found in jewelry?
Options: A. The diamond is cut into the shapes seen, B. The diamond must have grown in the earth’s mantle, C. The diamond must have grown in the presence of germanium, D. The diamond must have grown at very high pressure
Correct Option: A

Question 2: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a crystal? Options: A. Highly organized atomic arrangement, B. Highly disorganized atomic arrangement, C. Repeating pattern of atoms, D. Geometric shape Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the family of crystalline structures that includes quartz? Options: A. Cubic, B. Tetragonal, C. Hexagonal, D. Triclinic Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which of the following crystals has a cubic crystalline structure? Options: A. Galena, B. Quartz, C. Diamond, D. Turquoise Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary factor that determines the shape of a diamond crystal? Options: A. Temperature, B. Pressure, C. Chemical environment, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the process by which glass is made? Options: A. Crystallization, B. Melting, C. Cooling, D. Quenching Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why do crystals in rocks like granite not have recognizable shapes? Options: A. Because they grow in extremely close quarters with other crystals, B. Because they are made of a different type of mineral, C. Because they are formed at high temperatures, D. Because they are formed at low pressures Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the name of the family of crystalline structures that includes feldspar? Options: A. Cubic, B. Tetragonal, C. Orthorhombic, D. Monoclinic Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the primary application of crystals in materials science? Options: A. Their ability to conduct electricity, B. Their ability to conduct heat, C. Their unique properties, D. Their geometric shapes Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why do crystals like quartz not form geometric shapes in most environmental conditions? Options: A. Because they grow too quickly, B. Because they grow too slowly, C. Because they grow in extremely close quarters with other crystals, D. Because they are made of a different type of mineral Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 3 billion people around the world, seafood provides a significant source 
of protein and nutrition. But recent studies show that 33% of wild 
fisheries are overfished, while another 60% are fished at their 
maximum capacity. In fact, over half the seafood we eat– from finfish and shellfish to 
seaweed and algae– isn’t caught in the wild. It’s grown through aquaculture, 
or aquatic farming. Farmed seafood is one of the 
fastest-growing food industries, expanding in volume by 5.8% each year. But different methods of aquaculture come 
with different advantages and issues– some of which echo the serious problems 
we’ve seen in industrial agriculture. So how can we avoid repeating the mistakes
we’ve made on land, at sea? What aquaculture approaches are we 
currently using, and what does a sustainable way 
to farm the ocean really look like? One of the most common aquaculture 
methods involves large pens made of nets, where fish are farmed offshore in floating
cages roughly 1000 square meters in size. Commonly employed off the coast of Chile
and in the fjords of Norway, these fish, like many industrially 
farmed animals, occupy stressful, overcrowded pens. They produce massive amounts of waste, polluting the surrounding areas and potentially spreading diseases
to wild species. Worse still, since the antibiotics 
employed to fight disease aren’t fully absorbed by the fish, they get excreted back 
into the environment. Net pens are also susceptible to escapes, unleashing huge numbers of fish which 
compete for resources and weaken the local gene pool 
with genes adapted for captivity. Escaped fish can even disrupt local 
ecosystems as invasive species. Other techniques, such as man-made coastal ponds commonly
used for shrimp farming in Southeast Asia, create additional environmental problems. Just like net pens, these ponds are prone
to spreading pollution and disease. Their construction also frequently 
destroys important ecosystems like mangroves and marshes, which protect coastal areas from storms, provide habitats, and absorb tons 
of greenhouse gases. One way to solve these problems is to farm
fish on land in completely contained systems. Tanks and raceways can recirculate and 
filter water to prevent pollution. But even fully contained facilities still 
contend with another major hurdle: fishmeal. About 10% of the seafood caught globally
is used to feed animals, including carnivorous farmed fish. Researchers are working on fish feed made 
of insects and plant-based proteins, but for now many inland fish farms 
are connected to overfishing. All these obstacles can make sustainable 
aquaculture feel a long way off, but innovative farmers are finding new 
ways to responsibly farm the seas. The most promising solution of all 
may be to look lower on the food chain. Instead of cramming large, carnivorous 
fish into pens, we can work with natural ocean systems to produce huge amounts of shellfish 
and seaweeds. These low-maintenance flora and fauna 
don’t need to be fed at all. In fact, they naturally improve 
water quality, filtering it as they feed off of sunlight 
and nutrients in the seawater. By absorbing carbon through 
photosynthesis, these farms help battle climate change, and reduce local ocean acidification while creating habitats for other 
species to thrive. Shifting to restorative ocean farming could provide good jobs for 
coastal communities, and support healthy plant and 
shellfish-based diets that have an incredibly 
low carbon footprint. In just 5 months, 4,000 square meters of ocean can 
produce 25 tons of seaweed and 250,000 of shellfish. With the right distribution network, a series of small farms, collectively 
the size of Washington State could feed the planet. Farms like these are already popping up
around the globe, and a new generation of farmers is 
stepping up to pursue a more sustainable future. Done properly, regenerative ocean farming could play
a vital role in helping our oceans, our climate, and ourselves.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of wild fisheries are considered to be overfished?
Options: A. 60%, B. 93%, C. 30%, D. 33%, E. 63%
Correct Option: D

Question 3: What is aquaculture, and how is it expanding? Options: A. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in the wild, and it is expanding at a rate of 1% per year., B. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in controlled environments, and it is expanding at a rate of 5.8% per year., C. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in the wild, and it is expanding at a rate of 5.8% per year., D. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in controlled environments, and it is expanding at a rate of 1% per year. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What are some of the problems associated with net pens used in aquaculture? Options: A. They produce massive amounts of waste and pollute the surrounding areas., B. They are prone to spreading disease to wild species., C. They are susceptible to escapes, unleashing huge numbers of fish that compete for resources and weaken the local gene pool., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is one way to solve the problems associated with net pens? Options: A. By using man-made coastal ponds., B. By farming fish on land in completely contained systems., C. By using a combination of net pens and man-made coastal ponds., D. By not using net pens at all. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is one of the major hurdle that even fully contained facilities still contend with? Options: A. Fishmeal., B. Disease., C. Pollution., D. Overfishing. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is one of the most promising solutions to sustainable aquaculture? Options: A. Farming large, carnivorous fish in net pens., B. Farming shellfish and seaweeds in natural ocean systems., C. Using man-made coastal ponds., D. Farming fish on land in completely contained systems. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What are some of the benefits of farming shellfish and seaweeds in natural ocean systems? Options: A. They produce massive amounts of waste and pollute the surrounding areas., B. They are prone to spreading disease to wild species., C. They naturally improve water quality, filter it as they feed off of sunlight and nutrients in the seawater., D. They absorb carbon through photosynthesis, reducing local ocean acidification. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one of the potential benefits of regenerative ocean farming? Options: A. It can provide good jobs for coastal communities., B. It can support healthy plant and shellfish-based diets that have an incredibly low carbon footprint., C. It can help battle climate change., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential scale of regenerative ocean farming? Options: A. A single farm the size of a football field., B. A series of small farms, collectively the size of Washington State., C. A single farm the size of a city., D. A series of large farms, collectively the size of a country. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the correct option is not explicitly stated in Question 1, the question content and options are similar to the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the percentage of wild fisheries that are considered to be overfished, and the correct option is 33%. Question 1 also asks about the percentage of wild fisheries that are overfished, and option B is 33%, which matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Since there isn't a direct match, I will not provide an index for a matching generated MCQ. However, I can suggest creating a new generated MCQ that directly addresses the ground truth MCQ. For example:

Question: What species is commonly farmed in man-made coastal ponds?
Options: A. salmon, B. shrimp, C. catfish, D. tuna, E. oysters

This new generated MCQ would match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 3 billion people around the world, seafood provides a significant source 
of protein and nutrition. But recent studies show that 33% of wild 
fisheries are overfished, while another 60% are fished at their 
maximum capacity. In fact, over half the seafood we eat– from finfish and shellfish to 
seaweed and algae– isn’t caught in the wild. It’s grown through aquaculture, 
or aquatic farming. Farmed seafood is one of the 
fastest-growing food industries, expanding in volume by 5.8% each year. But different methods of aquaculture come 
with different advantages and issues– some of which echo the serious problems 
we’ve seen in industrial agriculture. So how can we avoid repeating the mistakes
we’ve made on land, at sea? What aquaculture approaches are we 
currently using, and what does a sustainable way 
to farm the ocean really look like? One of the most common aquaculture 
methods involves large pens made of nets, where fish are farmed offshore in floating
cages roughly 1000 square meters in size. Commonly employed off the coast of Chile
and in the fjords of Norway, these fish, like many industrially 
farmed animals, occupy stressful, overcrowded pens. They produce massive amounts of waste, polluting the surrounding areas and potentially spreading diseases
to wild species. Worse still, since the antibiotics 
employed to fight disease aren’t fully absorbed by the fish, they get excreted back 
into the environment. Net pens are also susceptible to escapes, unleashing huge numbers of fish which 
compete for resources and weaken the local gene pool 
with genes adapted for captivity. Escaped fish can even disrupt local 
ecosystems as invasive species. Other techniques, such as man-made coastal ponds commonly
used for shrimp farming in Southeast Asia, create additional environmental problems. Just like net pens, these ponds are prone
to spreading pollution and disease. Their construction also frequently 
destroys important ecosystems like mangroves and marshes, which protect coastal areas from storms, provide habitats, and absorb tons 
of greenhouse gases. One way to solve these problems is to farm
fish on land in completely contained systems. Tanks and raceways can recirculate and 
filter water to prevent pollution. But even fully contained facilities still 
contend with another major hurdle: fishmeal. About 10% of the seafood caught globally
is used to feed animals, including carnivorous farmed fish. Researchers are working on fish feed made 
of insects and plant-based proteins, but for now many inland fish farms 
are connected to overfishing. All these obstacles can make sustainable 
aquaculture feel a long way off, but innovative farmers are finding new 
ways to responsibly farm the seas. The most promising solution of all 
may be to look lower on the food chain. Instead of cramming large, carnivorous 
fish into pens, we can work with natural ocean systems to produce huge amounts of shellfish 
and seaweeds. These low-maintenance flora and fauna 
don’t need to be fed at all. In fact, they naturally improve 
water quality, filtering it as they feed off of sunlight 
and nutrients in the seawater. By absorbing carbon through 
photosynthesis, these farms help battle climate change, and reduce local ocean acidification while creating habitats for other 
species to thrive. Shifting to restorative ocean farming could provide good jobs for 
coastal communities, and support healthy plant and 
shellfish-based diets that have an incredibly 
low carbon footprint. In just 5 months, 4,000 square meters of ocean can 
produce 25 tons of seaweed and 250,000 of shellfish. With the right distribution network, a series of small farms, collectively 
the size of Washington State could feed the planet. Farms like these are already popping up
around the globe, and a new generation of farmers is 
stepping up to pursue a more sustainable future. Done properly, regenerative ocean farming could play
a vital role in helping our oceans, our climate, and ourselves.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Approximately how much of the seafood caught globally is used to feed farm animals and carnivorous fish?
Options: A. 10%, B. 33%, C. 90%, D. 50%, E. none of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of wild fisheries are overfished? Options: A. 20%, B. 33%, C. 50%, D. 60% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary source of protein and nutrition for 3 billion people around the world? Options: A. Meat, B. Seafood, C. Fruits and Vegetables, D. Grains Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is aquaculture, and how is it expanding? Options: A. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in the wild, and it is expanding at a rate of 1% per year., B. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in controlled environments, and it is expanding at a rate of 5.8% per year., C. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in the wild, and it is expanding at a rate of 5.8% per year., D. Aquaculture is the farming of fish in controlled environments, and it is expanding at a rate of 1% per year. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What are some of the problems associated with net pens used in aquaculture? Options: A. They produce massive amounts of waste and pollute the surrounding areas., B. They are prone to spreading disease to wild species., C. They are susceptible to escapes, unleashing huge numbers of fish that compete for resources and weaken the local gene pool., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is one way to solve the problems associated with net pens? Options: A. By using man-made coastal ponds., B. By farming fish on land in completely contained systems., C. By using a combination of net pens and man-made coastal ponds., D. By not using net pens at all. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is one of the major hurdle that even fully contained facilities still contend with? Options: A. Fishmeal., B. Disease., C. Pollution., D. Overfishing. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is one of the most promising solutions to sustainable aquaculture? Options: A. Farming large, carnivorous fish in net pens., B. Farming shellfish and seaweeds in natural ocean systems., C. Using man-made coastal ponds., D. Farming fish on land in completely contained systems. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What are some of the benefits of farming shellfish and seaweeds in natural ocean systems? Options: A. They produce massive amounts of waste and pollute the surrounding areas., B. They are prone to spreading disease to wild species., C. They naturally improve water quality, filter it as they feed off of sunlight and nutrients in the seawater., D. They absorb carbon through photosynthesis, reducing local ocean acidification. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one of the potential benefits of regenerative ocean farming? Options: A. It can provide good jobs for coastal communities., B. It can support healthy plant and shellfish-based diets that have an incredibly low carbon footprint., C. It can help battle climate change., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential scale of regenerative ocean farming? Options: A. A single farm the size of a football field., B. A series of small farms, collectively the size of Washington State., C. A single farm the size of a city., D. A series of large farms, collectively the size of a country. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What is one of the major hurdles that even fully contained facilities still contend with? Options: A. Fishmeal., B. Disease., C. Pollution., D. Overfishing.

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it deals with the topic of fishmeal, which is mentioned in the ground truth MCQ as the answer (10% of the seafood caught globally is used to feed farm animals and carnivorous fish). Although the generated MCQ does not ask about the specific percentage, it addresses the same issue of fishmeal being a major hurdle in aquaculture.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 3 billion people around the world, seafood provides a significant source 
of protein and nutrition. But recent studies show that 33% of wild 
fisheries are overfished, while another 60% are fished at their 
maximum capacity. In fact, over half the seafood we eat– from finfish and shellfish to 
seaweed and algae– isn’t caught in the wild. It’s grown through aquaculture, 
or aquatic farming. Farmed seafood is one of the 
fastest-growing food industries, expanding in volume by 5.8% each year. But different methods of aquaculture come 
with different advantages and issues– some of which echo the serious problems 
we’ve seen in industrial agriculture. So how can we avoid repeating the mistakes
we’ve made on land, at sea? What aquaculture approaches are we 
currently using, and what does a sustainable way 
to farm the ocean really look like? One of the most common aquaculture 
methods involves large pens made of nets, where fish are farmed offshore in floating
cages roughly 1000 square meters in size. Commonly employed off the coast of Chile
and in the fjords of Norway, these fish, like many industrially 
farmed animals, occupy stressful, overcrowded pens. They produce massive amounts of waste, polluting the surrounding areas and potentially spreading diseases
to wild species. Worse still, since the antibiotics 
employed to fight disease aren’t fully absorbed by the fish, they get excreted back 
into the environment. Net pens are also susceptible to escapes, unleashing huge numbers of fish which 
compete for resources and weaken the local gene pool 
with genes adapted for captivity. Escaped fish can even disrupt local 
ecosystems as invasive species. Other techniques, such as man-made coastal ponds commonly
used for shrimp farming in Southeast Asia, create additional environmental problems. Just like net pens, these ponds are prone
to spreading pollution and disease. Their construction also frequently 
destroys important ecosystems like mangroves and marshes, which protect coastal areas from storms, provide habitats, and absorb tons 
of greenhouse gases. One way to solve these problems is to farm
fish on land in completely contained systems. Tanks and raceways can recirculate and 
filter water to prevent pollution. But even fully contained facilities still 
contend with another major hurdle: fishmeal. About 10% of the seafood caught globally
is used to feed animals, including carnivorous farmed fish. Researchers are working on fish feed made 
of insects and plant-based proteins, but for now many inland fish farms 
are connected to overfishing. All these obstacles can make sustainable 
aquaculture feel a long way off, but innovative farmers are finding new 
ways to responsibly farm the seas. The most promising solution of all 
may be to look lower on the food chain. Instead of cramming large, carnivorous 
fish into pens, we can work with natural ocean systems to produce huge amounts of shellfish 
and seaweeds. These low-maintenance flora and fauna 
don’t need to be fed at all. In fact, they naturally improve 
water quality, filtering it as they feed off of sunlight 
and nutrients in the seawater. By absorbing carbon through 
photosynthesis, these farms help battle climate change, and reduce local ocean acidification while creating habitats for other 
species to thrive. Shifting to restorative ocean farming could provide good jobs for 
coastal communities, and support healthy plant and 
shellfish-based diets that have an incredibly 
low carbon footprint. In just 5 months, 4,000 square meters of ocean can 
produce 25 tons of seaweed and 250,000 of shellfish. With the right distribution network, a series of small farms, collectively 
the size of Washington State could feed the planet. Farms like these are already popping up
around the globe, and a new generation of farmers is 
stepping up to pursue a more sustainable future. Done properly, regenerative ocean farming could play
a vital role in helping our oceans, our climate, and ourselves.

Question: Which of the following is a benefit of regenerative ocean farming?
Options: A. absorbs carbon and produces oxygen, B. produces healthy food, C. creates jobs in coastal communities, D. improves water quality and reduces ocean acidification, E. all of the above
Correct Option: E

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The world is getting closer to achieving one of the most important 
public health goals of our time: eradicating HIV. And to do this, we won’t even have 
to cure the disease. We simply have to stop HIV from 
being transmitted until eventually it fizzles out. Once, this goal would have 
seemed impossible. HIV has caused millions of deaths and is one of the most devastating 
diseases that humanity has ever known. But we’re now at a point where new 
advances such as one-pill, once-a-day medications are helping us tackle HIV 
in effective ways. HIV is a retrovirus– meaning it integrates copies of itself 
into an infected cell’s DNA, allowing it to replicate and 
infect other cells. HIV has evolved numerous ways to evade 
the human immune system, which makes it difficult to cure. But by developing ways to 
block HIV replication, we can stop the spread of HIV itself. That’s where antiretrovirals–
a.k.a. ARVs– come in. ARVs are a group of drugs which work 
in different ways to combat HIV. Some block HIV’s access into immune cells, and others work by stopping the 
virus itself from replicating. ARVs also work preventatively in people 
who don’t have HIV. This type of approach is called 
pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP. PrEP works by accumulating in a 
person’s body and preventing HIV from 
establishing itself. That means an HIV-negative person who may
be at risk of contracting the disease can take certain ARVs 
to protect themselves, before they become exposed. Here’s where it gets 
especially interesting: In people with HIV, ARVs can also 
dramatically reduce HIV transmission. This is called “Treatment as Prevention.” On a global scale, this has the potential 
to end the HIV epidemic. It’s based on the idea that someone with
HIV who takes ARV’s can lower the virus level in their bodies
until it becomes undetectable. That doesn’t mean the virus is gone; it could still be lurking within cells, 
ready to reactivate if treatment stops. But so long as it’s kept 
dormant with drugs, HIV remains undetectable. And when HIV is undetectable, 
it’s untransmittable, too. In theory this means that by testing 
everyone who’s at risk of HIV and treating those who test positive, we could stop transmission and 
eventually eradicate HIV. In the real world, however, 
things are more complex. Many at-risk HIV negative people across 
the world do not have access to PrEP or ARVs, and those who are HIV positive may 
experience challenges to taking ARVs. These problems are often greatest in 
countries where the burden of HIV is highest. Getting these medications depends on 
access to a functioning healthcare system– and this isn’t something everyone has. That’s part of the reason why stopping 
the spread of HIV for good will require a significant investment of 
resources to improve those systems. One study carried out by the UNAIDS estimated that between 20-30 billion 
dollars per year would be needed to achieve 
a nearly 90% reduction in new HIV infections by 2030. This investment would ensure more people
would get tested in the first place, and more would be able to access and 
maintain treatment. Achieving this goal and improving 
healthcare in general is in everyone’s best interest, from individual people to 
society as a whole. We have roadmaps that could allow us to bring the HIV epidemic to an 
end in the near future, with the possibility of eradicating the 
disease altogether several generations in the future. In the period from 1996 to 2017 we almost halved the number 
of new HIV infections, and for the millions of people who still 
live with the virus, ARV treatments enable most to lead long 
and healthy lives. With continued and increased investments, we can get transmission rates low enough
to end HIV once and for all. A world without HIV is no longer 
inconceivable: it’s closer than ever.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following can prevent HIV transmission?
Options: A. Condoms, B. PrEP, C. Someone who is HIV positive and undetectable, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the goal that the world is getting closer to achieving in terms of public health? Options: A. Eradicating the cause of HIV, B. Stopping HIV from being transmitted until it fizzles out, C. Curing HIV, D. Developing a vaccine for HIV Correct Option: None
Question 2: What type of virus is HIV? Options: A. A retrovirus, B. A bacterium, C. A fungus, D. A virus that integrates into DNA Correct Option: None
Question 3: What are ARVs, and what do they do? Options: A. ARVs are a type of antiviral medication that only works for HIV-positive people, B. ARVs are a group of drugs that work in different ways to combat HIV, C. ARVs are a type of vaccine that prevents HIV, D. ARVs are a type of treatment that only works for HIV-negative people Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is PrEP, and how does it work? Options: A. PrEP is a type of treatment that only works for HIV-positive people, and it works by stopping the virus from replicating, B. PrEP is a type of preventive medication that works by accumulating in a person's body and preventing HIV from establishing itself, C. PrEP is a type of vaccine that prevents HIV, D. PrEP is a type of treatment that only works for HIV-negative people, and it works by blocking HIV's access into immune cells Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is "Treatment as Prevention," and how does it work? Options: A. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of treatment that only works for HIV-positive people, and it works by stopping the virus from replicating, B. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of preventive medication that works by accumulating in a person's body and preventing HIV from establishing itself, C. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of vaccine that prevents HIV, D. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of treatment that works by dramatically reducing HIV transmission in people with HIV Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the UNAIDS study, how much money would be needed to achieve a nearly 90% reduction in new HIV infections by 2030? Options: A. $10 billion per year, B. $20-30 billion per year, C. $50 billion per year, D. $100 billion per year Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the main challenge to stopping the spread of HIV in many countries? Options: A. Lack of access to PrEP, B. Lack of access to ARVs, C. Lack of access to a functioning healthcare system, D. Lack of funding for HIV research Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the goal of the roadmaps to bring the HIV epidemic to an end? Options: A. To cure HIV, B. To reduce the number of new HIV infections, C. To eradicate HIV, D. To improve healthcare systems Correct Option: None
Question 9: What has been the trend in the number of new HIV infections from 1996 to 2017? Options: A. The number of new HIV infections has increased by 50%, B. The number of new HIV infections has remained the same, C. The number of new HIV infections has decreased by 50%, D. The number of new HIV infections has increased by 100% Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential outcome of getting transmission rates low enough to end HIV? Options: A. A world with more HIV-positive people, B. A world with more HIV-negative people, C. A world without HIV, D. A world with a higher burden of HIV Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but Question 5 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since Question 5 does not have options that directly match the ground truth MCQ, I will also consider other questions.

Question 4 is about PrEP, which is one of the options in the ground truth MCQ. Question 3 is about ARVs, which is related to the topic of HIV transmission prevention.

Considering the options and content of the generated MCQs, I would say that none of the questions directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 4 is the closest, as it deals with PrEP, which is one of the options in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The world is getting closer to achieving one of the most important 
public health goals of our time: eradicating HIV. And to do this, we won’t even have 
to cure the disease. We simply have to stop HIV from 
being transmitted until eventually it fizzles out. Once, this goal would have 
seemed impossible. HIV has caused millions of deaths and is one of the most devastating

block HIV replication, we can stop the spread of HIV itself. That’s where antiretrovirals–
a.k.a. ARVs– come in. ARVs are a group of drugs which work 
in different ways to combat HIV. Some block HIV’s access into immune cells, and others work by stopping the

dramatically reduce HIV transmission. This is called “Treatment as Prevention.” On a global scale, this has the potential 
to end the HIV epidemic. It’s based on the idea that someone with

until it becomes undetectable. That doesn’t mean the virus is gone; it could still be lurking within cells, 
ready to reactivate if treatment stops. But so long as it’s kept 
dormant with drugs, HIV remains undetectable. And when HIV is undetectable, 
it’s untransmittable, too. In theory this means that by testing 
everyone who’s at risk of HIV and treating those who test positive, we could stop transmission and 
eventually eradicate HIV. In the real world, however, 
things are more complex. Many at-risk HIV negative people across 
the world do not have access to PrEP or ARVs, and those who are HIV positive may 
experience challenges to taking ARVs. These problems are often greatest in 
countries where the burden of HIV is highest. Getting these medications depends on 
access to a functioning healthcare system– and this isn’t something everyone has. That’s part of the reason why stopping 
the spread of HIV for good will require a significant investment of 
resources to improve those systems. One study carried out by the UNAIDS estimated that between 20-30 billion 
dollars per year would be needed to achieve 
a nearly 90% reduction in new HIV infections by 2030. This investment would ensure more people
would get tested in the first place, and more would be able to access and 
maintain treatment. Achieving this goal and improving 
healthcare in general is in everyone’s best interest, from individual people to 
society as a whole. We have roadmaps that could allow us to bring the HIV epidemic to an 
end in the near future, with the possibility of eradicating the 
disease altogether several generations in the future. In the period from 1996 to 2017 we almost halved the number 
of new HIV infections, and for the millions of people who still 
live with the virus, ARV treatments enable most to lead long 
and healthy lives. With continued and increased investments, we can get transmission rates low enough
to end HIV once and for all. A world without HIV is no longer 
inconceivable: it’s closer than ever.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Other sexually transmitted infections such as syphilis, gonorrhea, or chlamydia can increase your risk of being infected with HIV.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

The number of new HIV infections has remained the same, C. The number of new HIV infections has decreased by 50%, D. The number of new HIV infections has increased by 100% Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The world is getting closer to achieving one of the most important 
public health goals of our time: eradicating HIV. And to do this, we won’t even have 
to cure the disease. We simply have to stop HIV from 
being transmitted until eventually it fizzles out. Once, this goal would have 
seemed impossible. HIV has caused millions of deaths and is one of the most devastating 
diseases that humanity has ever known. But we’re now at a point where new 
advances such as one-pill, once-a-day medications are helping us tackle HIV 
in effective ways. HIV is a retrovirus– meaning it integrates copies of itself 
into an infected cell’s DNA, allowing it to replicate and 
infect other cells. HIV has evolved numerous ways to evade 
the human immune system, which makes it difficult to cure. But by developing ways to 
block HIV replication, we can stop the spread of HIV itself. That’s where antiretrovirals–
a.k.a. ARVs– come in. ARVs are a group of drugs which work 
in different ways to combat HIV. Some block HIV’s access into immune cells, and others work by stopping the 
virus itself from replicating. ARVs also work preventatively in people 
who don’t have HIV. This type of approach is called 
pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP. PrEP works by accumulating in a 
person’s body and preventing HIV from 
establishing itself. That means an HIV-negative person who may
be at risk of contracting the disease can take certain ARVs 
to protect themselves, before they become exposed. Here’s where it gets 
especially interesting: In people with HIV, ARVs can also 
dramatically reduce HIV transmission. This is called “Treatment as Prevention.” On a global scale, this has the potential 
to end the HIV epidemic. It’s based on the idea that someone with
HIV who takes ARV’s can lower the virus level in their bodies
until it becomes undetectable. That doesn’t mean the virus is gone; it could still be lurking within cells, 
ready to reactivate if treatment stops. But so long as it’s kept 
dormant with drugs, HIV remains undetectable. And when HIV is undetectable, 
it’s untransmittable, too. In theory this means that by testing 
everyone who’s at risk of HIV and treating those who test positive, we could stop transmission and 
eventually eradicate HIV. In the real world, however, 
things are more complex. Many at-risk HIV negative people across 
the world do not have access to PrEP or ARVs, and those who are HIV positive may 
experience challenges to taking ARVs. These problems are often greatest in 
countries where the burden of HIV is highest. Getting these medications depends on 
access to a functioning healthcare system– and this isn’t something everyone has. That’s part of the reason why stopping 
the spread of HIV for good will require a significant investment of 
resources to improve those systems. One study carried out by the UNAIDS estimated that between 20-30 billion 
dollars per year would be needed to achieve 
a nearly 90% reduction in new HIV infections by 2030. This investment would ensure more people
would get tested in the first place, and more would be able to access and 
maintain treatment. Achieving this goal and improving 
healthcare in general is in everyone’s best interest, from individual people to 
society as a whole. We have roadmaps that could allow us to bring the HIV epidemic to an 
end in the near future, with the possibility of eradicating the 
disease altogether several generations in the future. In the period from 1996 to 2017 we almost halved the number 
of new HIV infections, and for the millions of people who still 
live with the virus, ARV treatments enable most to lead long 
and healthy lives. With continued and increased investments, we can get transmission rates low enough
to end HIV once and for all. A world without HIV is no longer 
inconceivable: it’s closer than ever.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: People who are HIV positive may not feel sick and be unaware they are infected.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the goal that the world is getting closer to achieving in terms of public health? Options: A. Eradicating the cause of HIV, B. Stopping HIV from being transmitted until it fizzles out, C. Curing HIV, D. Developing a vaccine for HIV Correct Option: None
Question 2: What type of virus is HIV? Options: A. A retrovirus, B. A bacterium, C. A fungus, D. A virus that integrates into DNA Correct Option: None
Question 3: What are ARVs, and what do they do? Options: A. ARVs are a type of antiviral medication that only works for HIV-positive people, B. ARVs are a group of drugs that work in different ways to combat HIV, C. ARVs are a type of vaccine that prevents HIV, D. ARVs are a type of treatment that only works for HIV-negative people Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is PrEP, and how does it work? Options: A. PrEP is a type of treatment that only works for HIV-positive people, and it works by stopping the virus from replicating, B. PrEP is a type of preventive medication that works by accumulating in a person's body and preventing HIV from establishing itself, C. PrEP is a type of vaccine that prevents HIV, D. PrEP is a type of treatment that only works for HIV-negative people, and it works by blocking HIV's access into immune cells Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is "Treatment as Prevention," and how does it work? Options: A. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of treatment that only works for HIV-positive people, and it works by stopping the virus from replicating, B. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of preventive medication that works by accumulating in a person's body and preventing HIV from establishing itself, C. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of vaccine that prevents HIV, D. "Treatment as Prevention" is a type of treatment that works by dramatically reducing HIV transmission in people with HIV Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the UNAIDS study, how much money would be needed to achieve a nearly 90% reduction in new HIV infections by 2030? Options: A. $10 billion per year, B. $20-30 billion per year, C. $50 billion per year, D. $100 billion per year Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the main challenge to stopping the spread of HIV in many countries? Options: A. Lack of access to PrEP, B. Lack of access to ARVs, C. Lack of access to a functioning healthcare system, D. Lack of funding for HIV research Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the goal of the roadmaps to bring the HIV epidemic to an end? Options: A. To cure HIV, B. To reduce the number of new HIV infections, C. To eradicate HIV, D. To improve healthcare systems Correct Option: None
Question 9: What has been the trend in the number of new HIV infections from 1996 to 2017? Options: A. The number of new HIV infections has increased by 50%, B. The number of new HIV infections has remained the same, C. The number of new HIV infections has decreased by 50%, D. The number of new HIV infections has increased by 100% Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential outcome of getting transmission rates low enough to end HIV? Options: A. A world with more HIV-positive people, B. A world with more HIV-negative people, C. A world without HIV, D. A world with a higher burden of HIV Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Lack of access to ARVs, C. Lack of access to a functioning healthcare system, D. Lack of funding for HIV research.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4

**Transcript**:
The world is getting closer to achieving one of the most important 
public health goals of our time: eradicating HIV. And to do this, we won’t even have 
to cure the disease. We simply have to stop HIV from 
being transmitted until eventually it fizzles out. Once, this goal would have 
seemed impossible. HIV has caused millions of deaths and is one of the most devastating 
diseases that humanity has ever known. But we’re now at a point where new 
advances such as one-pill, once-a-day medications are helping us tackle HIV 
in effective ways. HIV is a retrovirus– meaning it integrates copies of itself 
into an infected cell’s DNA, allowing it to replicate and 
infect other cells. HIV has evolved numerous ways to evade 
the human immune system, which makes it difficult to cure. But by developing ways to 
block HIV replication, we can stop the spread of HIV itself. That’s where antiretrovirals–
a.k.a. ARVs– come in. ARVs are a group of drugs which work 
in different ways to combat HIV. Some block HIV’s access into immune cells, and others work by stopping the 
virus itself from replicating. ARVs also work preventatively in people 
who don’t have HIV. This type of approach is called 
pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP. PrEP works by accumulating in a 
person’s body and preventing HIV from 
establishing itself. That means an HIV-negative person who may
be at risk of contracting the disease can take certain ARVs 
to protect themselves, before they become exposed. Here’s where it gets 
especially interesting: In people with HIV, ARVs can also 
dramatically reduce HIV transmission. This is called “Treatment as Prevention.” On a global scale, this has the potential 
to end the HIV epidemic. It’s based on the idea that someone with
HIV who takes ARV’s can lower the virus level in their bodies
until it becomes undetectable. That doesn’t mean the virus is gone; it could still be lurking within cells, 
ready to reactivate if treatment stops. But so long as it’s kept 
dormant with drugs, HIV remains undetectable. And when HIV is undetectable, 
it’s untransmittable, too. In theory this means that by testing 
everyone who’s at risk of HIV and treating those who test positive, we could stop transmission and 
eventually eradicate HIV. In the real world, however, 
things are more complex. Many at-risk HIV negative people across 
the world do not have access to PrEP or ARVs, and those who are HIV positive may 
experience challenges to taking ARVs. These problems are often greatest in 
countries where the burden of HIV is highest. Getting these medications depends on 
access to a functioning healthcare system– and this isn’t something everyone has. That’s part of the reason why stopping 
the spread of HIV for good will require a significant investment of 
resources to improve those systems. One study carried out by the UNAIDS estimated that between 20-30 billion 
dollars per year would be needed to achieve 
a nearly 90% reduction in new HIV infections by 2030. This investment would ensure more people
would get tested in the first place, and more would be able to access and 
maintain treatment. Achieving this goal and improving 
healthcare in general is in everyone’s best interest, from individual people to 
society as a whole. We have roadmaps that could allow us to bring the HIV epidemic to an 
end in the near future, with the possibility of eradicating the 
disease altogether several generations in the future. In the period from 1996 to 2017 we almost halved the number 
of new HIV infections, and for the millions of people who still 
live with the virus, ARV treatments enable most to lead long 
and healthy lives. With continued and increased investments, we can get transmission rates low enough
to end HIV once and for all. A world without HIV is no longer 
inconceivable: it’s closer than ever.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Someone who is HIV positive and “undetectable” on antiretrovirals can still transmit HIV.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B
